author: Marissa Lordanic
title: Matildas have questions to answer everywhere after Olympic humbling by Germany
text: Whatever the expectation was heading into the [Matildas](/football/team/_/id/2751/australia)' opening match of the [Olympic women's football tournament](/football/league/_/name/fifa.w.olympics), against [Germany](/football/team?id=2756), surely no one was expecting that. Goals to [Marina Hegering](https://www.espn.com/soccer/player/_/id/286459/marina-hegering), [Lea SchÃ¼ller](/soccer/player/_/id/258844/lea-schuller), and [Jule Brand](https://www.espn.com/soccer/player/_/id/317719/jule-brand) gave the 2016 Olympic champions a [3-0 win](/football/match/_/gameId/699835/australia-germany) and the perfect opening to their tournament. For the Matildas, it was a horror start, a tough watch in the middle of the night for those back home, and a wakeup call according to captain [Steph Catley](https://www.espn.com/soccer/player/_/id/219822/steph-catley). Morale was high with Catley and [Caitlin Foord](https://www.espn.com/soccer/player/_/id/158678/caitlin-foord) both deemed healthy enough to start after injury and precaution had kept them out of the Matildas' final warmup game against [Canada](/football/team?id=2753). Although [Tameka Yallop](https://www.espn.com/soccer/player/_/id/158688/tameka-yallop) was ruled out and replaced in the 18 by [Sharn Freier](https://www.espn.com/soccer/player/_/id/312197/sharn-freier), there was nothing obvious to worry about, personnel wise. But what followed was one of the worst games of consequence played by the Matildas under Tony Gustavsson. Moreover, it was confusing in how un-Matildas-like it was -- not just in defence but in attack. One of the strongest transformations under Gustavsson has been the Matildas' defensive stocks. It's an area of the pitch where assistant coach Jens Fjellstrom gets a lot of credit, and rightly so. Under his guidance and direction, the Australians have been able to nip silly defensive errors in the bud. There has been a concerted focus on set-piece defending, learning not to panic, and fostering stronger connections between the back four. And over the course of the past three-and-a-half years, the proof had been in the pudding. But the team's usual defensive solidity looked like it had been packed in the luggage that got lost on the team's charter flight from the training camp in Marbella to Marseille. Both Hegering and SchÃ¼ller scored free headers from [Giulia Gwinn](/soccer/player/_/id/268102/giulia-gwinn) corners: Hegering ghosted between [Ellie Carpenter](https://www.espn.com/soccer/player/_/id/236710/ellie-carpenter) and [Alanna Kennedy](https://www.espn.com/soccer/player/_/id/219819/alanna-kennedy) at the far post while SchÃ¼ller was simply left to her own devices, completely unmarked. If not for an offside [Alexandra Popp](/soccer/player/_/id/158735/alexandra-popp), Germany could have easily had a hat trick of easy, headed goals. It immediately bore dozens of memes, all using [Sam Kerr](https://www.espn.com/soccer/player/_/id/158683/sam-kerr)'s quote about the [USWNT](/football/team/_/id/2765/united-states)'s record on defending set pieces -- "do youse not work on that?" -- from the Netflix documentary on the team's 2023 [FIFA Women's World Cup](/football/league/_/name/fifa.wwc). Ultimately, the first two goals were undeniable errors that the Matildas will be filthy with. And perhaps if they had been the only goals conceded, the aftermath wouldn't feel as bad as it does. But Germany's third goal was a team move that saw the Matildas a beat behind for the entire passage, with Brand tapping the ball into the back of the net. Those in yellow looked like dancers who hadn't been given the choreography but were trying their best to not to look out of place. Naturally, the talk postgame was about how those mistakes must be eliminated and quickly. But defensive errors aren't the only thing that require tweaking ahead of the [Zambia](/football/team?id=20795) clash on Monday (AEST). [Australia](/football/team?id=2751) also struggled up front; this was a scenario that felt more likely than the defensive stumbles but it was no less disappointing to watch. Gustavsson chose to employ [Cortnee Vine](https://www.espn.com/soccer/player/_/id/300517/cortnee-vine) as the No. 9. It was a decision that prioritised [Mary Fowler](https://www.espn.com/soccer/player/_/id/276165/mary-fowler) as a free-roaming No. 10 with Foord out on the left to work in combination with her [Arsenal](/football/team?id=19973) teammate, Catley -- a connection Gustavsson leans on time and time again. But Vine as the central striker looked as untested as it felt. The general wisdom that [Michelle Heyman](https://www.espn.com/soccer/player/_/id/158675/michelle-heyman) would be better selected in the Matildas' second fixture since she can't play consecutive 90-minute games; but Vine as the next woman in to occupy that central space up top wasn't right either. On top of that, the Catley-Foord combination failed to capitalise on their bright moments while Fowler was unable to impact that game in the way she -- and Gustavsson and the nation -- wanted or needed. It begs the question: Do Gustavsson's attacking priorities need to be changed? Should Fowler be deployed out wide where she enjoyed success at club level? Does shifting Foord more central solve the No. 9 problem? Is there value in reprising the Fowler and [Emily van Egmond](https://www.espn.com/soccer/player/_/id/158693/emily-van-egmond) double false No. 9 that enjoyed success in the small sample of games at the World Cup? Would that in any way solve the seeming disconnect between the midfield and the forward line in this game? These are the questions both Gustavsson and his team will ponder as they recover and immediately shift focus to Zambia in Nice. A lot needs to be tweaked in an incredibly short amount of time if the Matildas are to keep their medal dreams alive.

author: JILLIAN KRAMER | Staff writer
title: Despite witnesses who forgot the crime, New Orleans jury finds man guilty of murder
text: A New Orleans jury late Wednesday night convicted a man of [shooting another man to death](https://www.nola.com/news/crime_police/two-stabbed-uptown-armed-robbery-reported-in-new-orleans-over-24-hour-period/article_ef20e2c2-f14d-11eb-b566-afd31cbed4fe.html) three years ago in Treme, in what prosecutors described as a drug-infested apartment complex. The jury found 44-year-old Barry Bowie guilty as charged of second-degree murder, obstruction of justice and possession of a firearm by a felon in the June 7, 2021 killing of Henry James in the 1900 block of St. Ann Street. According to an affidavit for an arrest warrant, witnesses told New Orleans police that the men had argued at the apartments before Bowie shot James multiple times. But when prosecutors Forrest Ladd and Carlos Torres called four alleged eyewitnesses to the stand, they told a different story: They were high on drugs and couldnâ€™t remember anything. A fifth eyewitness died of an overdose, prosecutors said, before he could testify. Instead, over the three-day trial this week in Orleans Parish Criminal District Court, prosecutors showed surveillance footage that placed Bowie at the crime scene holding what appeared to be a handgun, as well as other video footage that tracked his movements throughout the evening. Defense attorneys Judson Mitchell and Jessica Natal argued that without witnesses to identify Bowie as the killer, his mere presence at the scene wasnâ€™t enough to convict him. Prosecutors also played a jail call during which Bowie admitting to being at the shooting. But the clip, Natal argued, only proved that Bowie had fled after the gunfire like several other bystanders. The jury deliberated for four hours, until just after 10 p.m., before it delivered its guilty verdict. Criminal District Court Judge Kimya Holmes scheduled Bowieâ€™s sentencing hearing, where he will face a mandatory life-in-prison sentence, for July 31.

title: Maindrop, la revoluciÃ³n en el sector de la griferÃ­a
text:
Maindrop, la revoluciÃ³n en el sector de la griferÃ­a
Maindrop es mucho mÃ¡s que un nuevo concepto de griferÃ­a, ya que, gracias a la tecnologÃ­a mÃ¡s avanzada e innovadora, garantiza una alta eficiencia hÃ­drica y energÃ©tica a la vez que aporta comodidad y experiencia de usuario a unos niveles todavÃ­a no alcanzados.
Maindrop aplica la tecnologÃ­a de vanguardia para mejorar la experiencia de usuario y la eficiencia hidrÃ¡ulica y energÃ©tica en las griferÃ­as para baÃ±o y cocina.
Tanto para baÃ±o como para cocinas, Maindrop fusiona la mecatrÃ³nica mÃ¡s avanzada con la esencia mÃ¡s pura de la tecnologÃ­a de discos cerÃ¡micos, dando como resultado el equipo hidrÃ¡ulico electrÃ³nico mÃ¡s eficiente y robusto del sector de la griferÃ­a.
AdemÃ¡s, proporciona inteligencia y comunicaciÃ³n a todos y cada uno de los puntos de consumo de agua en un edificio o una casa, clave para generar â€˜redes inteligentesâ€™ reales y eficaces, capaces de desplegar aplicaciones y soluciones que garanticen un gran ahorro y una comodidad inigualable, mediante la tecnologÃ­a mÃ¡s avanzada:
- MCU. Es el corazÃ³n y el cerebro de cada grifo Maindrop. El corazÃ³n con tecnologÃ­a de discos cerÃ¡micos y la microelectrÃ³nica de alta precisiÃ³n para el cerebro.
- RW. La tecnologÃ­a RW es una tecnologÃ­a patentada, integrada en toda la gama de grifos Maindrop, que les dota de la capacidad de suministrar agua caliente a la temperatura solicitada por el usuario desde el primer momento del suministro.
- MI. Es un enchufe inteligente equipado con conectividad WiFi diseÃ±ado para interactuar con toda la gama de grifos Maindrop permitiÃ©ndoles establecer un diÃ¡logo directo y permanente con la zona de producciÃ³n de agua caliente (ACS).
- WIK. Es el interlocutor con el que el usuario establece un diÃ¡logo con los grifos Maindrop durante su uso, proporcionando un control total sobre ellos que se traduce en una experiencia de usuario inigualable.
- APP. A travÃ©s de una aplicaciÃ³n se puede acceder a todos los grifos y dispositivos Maindrop, para una conexiÃ³n rÃ¡pida y fÃ¡cil a su red WiFi.
Un sistema revolucionario para griferÃ­a que se presentarÃ¡ en exclusiva en Rebuild, en su stand 10G782.

title: Cae red de pedÃ³filos que engaÃ±aban a menores extranjeras en CÃºcuta
text:
CÃºcuta
Desde la direcciÃ³n de protecciÃ³n de la FiscalÃ­a General , se llevÃ³ a cabo la investigaciÃ³n y allanamientos a varios inmuebles, donde eran sometidas sexualmente menores de edad, engaÃ±adas por esta red criminal en zona de frontera.
Cerca de un aÃ±o durÃ³ la investigaciÃ³n que logrÃ³ la captura de los criminales dedicados a engaÃ±ar menores entre los 14 y 17 aÃ±os , de nacionalidad extranjera , haciÃ©ndose pasar por niÃ±os por medio de redes sociales o portales de juegos, y tambiÃ©n como empresarios, ofreciÃ©ndoles algÃºn tipo de trabajo.
MÃ¡s informaciÃ³n
Desmantelada banda dedicada a la falsificaciÃ³n de dÃ³lares y pesos en frontera Las menores eran citadas, una vez lograban tenerlas, eran llevabas a casas, donde eran drogadas y sometidas sexualmente en pequeÃ±os cuartos. Actos que eran grabados para luego vender los videos a depredadores sexuales.
El operativo tambiÃ©n se adelantÃ³ en otras ciudades de Colombia, dejando un total de 11 personas capturas y al menos 10 menores rescatadas por las autoridades. AdemÃ¡s, los inmuebles donde eran cometidos estos actos fueron sometidos a proceso de extinciÃ³n de dominio.

author: @thecolumbian
title: Surf pounds West Coast, Hawaii, causes flooding - The Columbian
text: LOS ANGELES â€” Powerful surf rolled onto beaches on the West Coast and Hawaii on Thursday as a big swell generated by the stormy Pacific Ocean pushed toward shorelines, causing localized flooding. Forecasters urged people to stay off rocks and jetties, and to not turn their backs to the ocean because of the danger of â€œsneaker wavesâ€ â€” occasional much bigger waves that can run far up the sand and wash someone off a beach. A high surf warning for parts of Northern California said waves would range from 28 to 33 feet and up to 40 feet at some locations, the National Weather Service said, adding that there were reports of flooding in low-lying coastal areas. In Aptos on the north end of Monterey Bay, surf overran the beach and swept into a parking lot, leaving the area strewn with debris. Santa Cruz County issued warnings for people in several coastal areas to be ready to evacuate. â€œMother Natureâ€™s angry,â€ said Eve Krammer, an Aptos resident for several years. â€œI mean these waves are gnarly. Theyâ€™re huge.â€ The same area was battered by the ocean last January as the West Coast was slammed by numerous atmospheric rivers. â€œI feel for the people that are down low here,â€ said Jeff Howard, also an Aptos resident. While not quite as huge, the waves along Southern California were also described as hazardous, with life-threatening rip currents. Nonetheless, surfers couldnâ€™t resist. Patience was key, according to Alex Buford, 27, who was catching waves just north of Manhattan Beach on the Los Angeles County coast. â€œI was waiting for awhile because the waves were really sick, and theyâ€™re kinda hard to get into even though I have a really big board,â€ he said. â€œJust waited for a good one and I got it and it was a long one. Pretty big. It was sick.â€ In Hawaii, the weather service forecast surf rising to 30 to 40 feet along north-facing shores and 18 to 22 feet along west-facing shores of five islands. Professional Hawaii surfer Sheldon Paishon was getting ready to surf Thursday morning at Makaha, a world-famous surfing beach on Oahuâ€™s west side. Paishon, 30, has been surfing at various spots around Oahu this week, taking advantage of waves during this weekâ€™s high surf warning in effect till this morning. â€œItâ€™s always big waves in the winter time in Hawaii,â€ he said. He warned that novice surfers should check with lifeguards before heading into the water and â€œmake sure you got some people around you and stay safe.â€ Honolulu Ocean Safety lifeguards, posted at beaches across Oahu, rescued 20 people along the islandâ€™s famed North Shore on Wednesday, said spokesperson Shayne Enright. They were also busy with thousands of â€œpreventative actions,â€ she said. â€œThis time of year produces incredible surf but it can also be very dangerous,â€ she said. The dangerous surf could also cause surges that could hit coastal properties and roadways, the weather service warned.

author: STERN.de
title: Ausbildung: Zahl der Pflege-Absolventen in ThÃ¼ringen konstant
text:
Die Zahl der Pflege-Azubis, die ihre Ausbildung erfolgreich beenden, stagniert in ThÃ¼ringen. Im vergangenen Jahr schlossen nach Angaben des Statistischen Landesamtes 890 Frauen und MÃ¤nner ihre Pflege-Ausbildung ab. Die meisten â€“ 879 â€“ entschieden sich fÃ¼r den fachÃ¼bergreifenden Abschluss als Pflegefachfrau oder Pflegefachmann. Elf Absolventen haben einen Abschluss mit dem Schwerpunkt Gesundheits- und Kinderkrankenpflege in der Tasche. Seit einer Reform der Pflegeausbildung 2020 durchlaufen angehende Kranken-, Alten- und KinderkrankenpflegekrÃ¤fte eine weitgehend vereinheitlichte Ausbildung.
Ende 2024 befanden sich laut Landesamt insgesamt 4.005 Personen in der Ausbildung zum Pflegefachmann oder zur Pflegefachfrau. 1.684 von ihnen absolvierten ihr erstes Ausbildungsjahr.
